intro: Diplocaulobium carolinense, commonly known as the Carolina water clover, is a herbaceous plant native to the southeastern United States. It belongs to the family Apiaceae, which includes many aromatic and edible plants. The plant is characterized by its finely divided, fern-like leaves that are often submerged or floating in aquatic environments. Its flowers are small and white, arranged in umbels, typical of the Apiaceae family. The plant is adapted to wetland habitats and plays a role in stabilizing aquatic ecosystems.
